This is an executive summary of the policies, procedures, and activities for compliance with the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Requirements - Risk Management Program pursuant to Title 40 Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68) for the Roehm Bay Citys MMA Production Plant.

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:
Roehm has a strongly committed to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training site personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the facility's processes. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies. Roehm MMA plant is a non-responding facility for releases of the RMP-listed chemicals , so the site utilizes an Emergency Action Plan.

The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:
The Roehm Methyl Methacrylate (MMA) production facility in Bay City, Texas, has one regulated flammable substance and one toxic substance identified for the Accidental Release Prevention Program (40 CFR Part 68.130), both exceeding the Threshold Quantity (TQ). The LiMA project at this facility includes a Methacrolein (MAL) production unit, a Methyl Methacrylate (MMA) production unit, and a Formaldehyde (FO) production unit.

Roehm Bay City facility stores and handles Dimethylamine (DMA) and Formaldehyde (FOL) in quantities that exceed the RMP threshold quantities of 10,000 lbs and 15,000 lbs, respectively.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]:
The following is a summary of the accident prevention program in place for the covere

d process at the facility. Roehm has a program in place to comply with the provisions of the accidental release prevention regulations under 40 CFR Part 68. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the existing release prevention program.

Process Safety Information [40 CFR Part 68.65]
Roehm maintains a detailed record of process safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.

Process Hazard Analysis [40 CFR Part 68.67]
Comprehensive analyses ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently. The methodology used to carry out these analyses is HAZOP (Hazard and Operability). The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of 5 years. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Written Operating Procedures [40 CFR Part 68.69]
To ensure safe operations, Roehm maintains detailed written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations and normal shutdown. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Employee Training [40 CFR Part 68.71]
Roehm has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating plant processes are competent in the applicable operating procedures. Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity [40 CFR Part 68.73]
Roehm carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations. Inspected process equipment include pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, pressure relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. Maintenance oper

ations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change [MOC] [40 CFR Part 68.75]
Written procedures are in place at Roehm to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures. Facility operators or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification(s).

Pre-Startup Safety Review [PSSR] [40 CFR Part 68.77]
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and modifications to existing processes are conducted routinely at Roehm. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits [40 CFR Part 68.79]
Roehm conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the US EPA RMP and OSHA PSM regulations are being implemented. These audits are conducted at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a prompt manner.

Incident Investigation [40 CFR Part 68.81]
Roehm promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum period of 5 years.

Employee Participation [40 CFR Part 68.83]
Roehm believes that Process Safety Management and accident prevention is a team effort. Employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. I

n addition, Roehm employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP and PSM rules, including information resulting from Process Hazard Analyses in particular.

Hot Work Permit [40 CFR Part 68.85]
Roehm has a hot work permit that requires issuance of a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near the covered process. 

Contractor Safety Program [40 CFR Part 68.87] 
Roehm occasionally hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is carried out. Roehm has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards associated with the contractor's work and the corresponding processes. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.

The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]:
The facilitys RMP process is new and therefore has had no accidents.

The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:
The Roehm retains a written site-specific formal emergency action plan (EAP), which includes the designated actions the company and all personnel will take to ensure personal safety from fire, unwanted releases of highly hazardous chemicals, and other emergencies.  The intent of this plan is to facilitate the prompt evacuation of employees when necessary and to account for all personnel.  The emergency plan also includes procedures for handling small releases. This facility is a non-responding facility and relies on the Local Fire Department to respond to chemical releases. 

Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]:
Roehm plans to continue to evaluate the regulated process as required under the PSM/RMP standards to ensure safe operations. The site is working to address the recommendations from their most recent PHA study and Compliance Audit to ensure continuous r

isk reduction.

Roehm has completed this report to provide the public with information about our activities at this facility.  We believe that the many controls instituted to maintain a safe operation, and our commitment to continuous improvement that an incident affecting our employees or the surrounding area is unlikely to occur.
